did.abstract: Director of psychological training at the Menninger Foundation (1951-1966); professor of psychology at the University of Michigan (1967-1999); associate director (1967-1973), later co-director (1974-1981) of the Psychological Clinic at the University of Michigan. The collection consists of correspondence, drafts of writings, published articles, research notes, lecture outlines and transcripts, audio recordings of lectures, committee minutes, and psychodiagnostic scales and tests.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of the children of Martin Mayman (Donor no. 8949) and came to the library in 2000.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Donor retains literary rights; researchers may quote up to 200 words without permission.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Martin Mayman papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Martin Mayman was born April 2, 1924 in New York. He received his B.S. in mathematics and psychology from City College of New York in 1943, his M.S. in psychology from New York University in 1947 and his Ph.D. in psychology from the University of Kansas in 1953.

From 1951 to 1966, Mayman was director of psychological training at the Menninger Foundation in Topeka, Kansas, where he founded and directed the post-doctoral training program in clinical psychology and pioneered several well-known psychodiagnostic procedures, such as the Early Memories Test.

Mayman completed psychoanalytic training at the Topeka Institute for Psychoanalysis. He came to the University of Michigan as a visiting professor in 1966 and became professor of psychology in 1967. Mayman retired in 1997 from active faculty status. On March 20, 1998, the Regents of the University of Michigan granted Mayman emeritus status.

In addition to being a professor of psychology at the University of Michigan, Mayman was a clinical psychologist at the Psychological Clinic, Institute of Human Adjustment. Additionally, Mayman served as the associate director of the Psychological Clinic from 1967 to 1973 and as its co-director from 1974 to 1981. The Psychological Clinic was founded in the 1950s under a special Rackham Endowment.

Mayman's early research focused on personality assessment, psychological testing and projective techniques. He later became interested in the subject of shame and its role in development and psychopathology.

Mayman was a prolific author, writing on topics such as Early Memories, the Rorschach, Psychopathology, and Clinical Psychology. He authored or co-authored 28 articles on psychological testing, many of which have become classics in the field. Mayman was also the recipient of many awards from professional organizations, receiving, among others, the Distinguished Contributions Award from the Society for Personality Assessment, the Distinguished Service to the Profession of Psychoanalysis Award from the American Psychological Association, Division 39, and the Distinguished Contribution to Psychology Award from City College of New York.

scopecontent.p: The Martin Mayman collection has been arranged into five series: Correspondence, Writings, Drafts and Notes, Seminars/Courses, Subject Files, Menninger Clinic, and UM Psychological Clinic.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Early memories.
Psychology.
Psychological tests.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Dept. of Psychology.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence series contains communications between Mayman and other academics and professionals in the field of psychology. The correspondence primarily discusses Mayman's research and writings. Correspondence regarding the internal activities of the Menninger Clinic and the UM Psychological Clinic has not been included in this series. The series has been arranged chronologically.

Writings, Drafts and Notes series documents Mayman's prolific career as a published author and co-author. The series has been arranged chronologically to help illustrate the evolution of Mayman's writing and research interests. Many articles contain multiple dates. This usually indicates that multiple drafts and re-writes have been included in the folder. The files usually contain multiple edited versions of the particular writing rather than the published version. Co-authors have not been indicated in the finding aid.

scopecontent.p: Seminars/Courses series includes teaching material from Mayman's time as a clinical instructor and psychology professor at the Menninger Foundation and the University of Michigan. The course material related to Menninger Foundation has been arranged chronologically and is reflective of Mayman's early research interests in personality assessment, psychodiagnostic testing, and Rorschach psychology. The seminars and courses taught by Mayman at the University of Michigan have been arranged alphabetically by class name. The series also contains transcripts from seminars conducted by Mayman at the York Wood Center and lecture outlines and drafts from various symposiums and conferences attended by Mayman. The series consists primarily of lecture outlines and transcripts, syllabi, audiocassette recordings of lectures, reading lists, and course handouts and exams.

did.unittitle: Clinical Use of Dream Interpretation Course 1958

Miscellaneous Lecture Outlines from Department of Psychology 1991

scopecontent.p: Subject Files series reflects Mayman's many research interests from personality assessment to self and object representation in early memories to Rorschach psychology. This series is helpful when compared with the Writings, Drafts and Notes series because it contains the research material used to help formulate many of Mayman's published arguments and conclusions. The Subject Files have been arranged alphabetically and are made up of assessment forms, testing scales, lecture transcripts, and research notes. Some of the files contain papers with a number written in the corner. These numbers correspondence to the Filing System Index created by Mayman in 1990-1991, which is also included in the Subject Files. However, it should be noted that the Filing System is not very consistent and is incomplete.

scopecontent.p: Menninger Clinic series documents the research and administrative activities of the Menninger Clinic. Materials related to the administrative activities of the Clinic include correspondence, committee minutes, and background information on the history and functioning of the Menninger Clinic and Foundation. The majority of the papers in the series are related to research conducted by Mayman during his tenure with the Menninger Clinic. The materials related to the research done at the Menninger Clinic consist primarily of assessment forms, testing scales, correspondence, lab reports and findings.

scopecontent.p: UM Psychological Clinic series contains papers related to the overall functioning of the Psychology Clinic including correspondence, committee minutes and reports, budgets, program evaluations, testing guidelines, and research proposals. The series also contains materials related to institutions associated with the Clinic, such as the Detroit Psychiatric Institute, the Michigan Psychoanalytic Institute, and the Michigan Psychological Association.
